commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Added basic editing features

You can now change the type of any brick just by selecting the kind of
brick you want and clicking on the level.

Next up is saving and loading. I think I'll skip filepicker dialogs,
cause they're hard.

Then I will jump into getting a single level playable in the game.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message: Added a second button, fixed the button event polling mechanism so button events dont fire multiple times for a single click.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Rudimentary button leveraging event framework is complete

I have implemented a basic button using the event framework. Right now
the editor just has the one button that closes the window, and it's
hardcoded to be totally black, but it's an important start.

Next I will add buttons to toggle between brick types and add
functionality to paint a level. After that, saving and loading and file picker
dialogs will flow.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Successfully rendered test level

The editor can now successfully render a level (with the path hard
coded). The level rendering code is in it's own library so that it can
be used by the game as well as the editor.

The next step is to get some UI buttons into the editor, again with the
UI code in a separate library, so that we can start loading/modifying
and saving out levels.

The hardest will be a file selector.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Got an editor window up.

I'm creating the code to render a level in a separate file so that it
can be used by both the game and the editor. Right now, I just have the
editor throwing a window up. Next is to include the LevelView and get it
to render into the window.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Completed level functionality

Added a level class that represents a Breakout level. It is capable of
saving and loading to a file, adding, removing and changing bricks at
given cells, and testing intersection and removing bricks on
intersection.

Next, I will start on the code to render a level, and from there will
work up to taking input to add and remove bricks.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
All tests pass, with the exception of input tests

I decided to skip over the input tests, as we are no longer using
eventing for each object to talk to each other, and it didn't make sense
to test SFML.

Next up, I'm going to start exploratory programming a file format for
the game levels.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Finished brick and collidable unit tests.

Implemented a generic reflection algorithm after all, that takes into
account the rotation of the surface and changes the ball's heading
appropriately. The algorithm is surprisingly succinct, AND makes fudging
the heading to prevent oscillation surprisingly easy.

Now to finish the last of the tests, and get started on a file format.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Added unit tests for Brick class

I'm slowly finishing tests for classes that I already have. After I have
finished writing tests, I will write an editor.
I think I will start with the file format, and write a class that can
save a Breakout board to the format, and construct a board from the
format.

Then I will start doing some UI work for the editor.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Simplified the component architecture with some generic programming.

While reading about memory management in C++, I realized I can use
generic programming to simplify the design of the object composition
framework.

I also upgraded the makefile generator to detect includes from source
files and headers to compile unit tests properly.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message: Stopped file generators from clobering existing files
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Implemented collidable and dimension features

Implemented 2 components - collidable and dimension. These components
give x,y and width/height properties onto the owner, and allows the
owner to test whether or not it collides with x,y co-ordinates.

I also realized that I can simplify the design of the game by
introducing a Breakout class that is responsible for holding all bricks
in a level and querying each brick for intersection with the ball.

This actually removes the need for the event framework, but I will leave
it in for now.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Implemented simple subscribe/notify, simplified architecture

As it turns out, making the EventManager a singleton eliminates the need
for a complicated EventManager/EventInterface structure. This simplifies
the interface for listening to and dispatching events, and as it
stands, I'm not using the composition framework.

However, it's there and has tests for it, so I will definitely make sure
it comes in handy for other functionality.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Improved Makefile generator to include test dependencies

The Makefile generator will now sniff for dependencies in tests and
include them in linking the final binary.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Still writing tests, figuring out architecture

Due to writing tests first, I have enountered the need for a slightly
more complex architecture. In order to support composition instead of
inheritance, I need a composition framework where objects can add
features in their constructors and be queried for other objects for
feature support. I am writing tests for this composition framework now.

I also have added to the utilities I'm using so that I can generate
classes, headers and unit test skeletons that will compile.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Tests now build and run, and fail

I wrote another utility to generate files for which I have created
tests. This will bootstrap the tests so that they compile and run,
saving me a lot of grunt work.

This will enable me in future projects to write the tests first,
generate the source file and header for every class there's a test for.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Got a blank screen up and rendering

Kind of like a "hello world" of game development.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Finished Makefile

Makefile now supports making and running unit tests in a more general
fashion. I will only need to add the unit test to a list of all tests,
and they will automatically be built and run.

I think if a test fails, the build will not continue, but I'm not sure
and it's not important.

Now I can start writing test cases.
commit_list.repo_description: A Breakout clone in C++ and SFML

commit_list.message:
Setting up unit tests

Using googletest as the C++ unit testing framework. Setting up Makefile
to work with building both the game and the tests.

Right now, those Makefiles are separate. I need to combine them into a
single Makefile that works.

commit_list.message:
Added an inheritance feature

One literati file can now inherit from another. The file that is
inheriting gets all the literati blocks of the inherited file, and can
override blocks by declaring a block with the same name.

The motivation for this feature is from incrementally describing a
program. Sometimes, especially when writing books or blog posts, you
want to slowly discuss changes to files, especially as you're building
up something complex.

Having old statements around that describe something covered in a
previous post or section can be confusing.

Instead, now you can just describe the changes, inheriting from another
literati file. The generated documentation will just have the new
statement sections, however the generated source will have the inherited
code as well as new/changed code.
commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.message:
Packaged literati as a gem with an executable.

This will allow me to use literati on itself, so that I only need to
write in literati to write literati source code.

Also will allow me to start writing some serious projects in literati
and make it part of their build processes.
commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.message:
Weave and tangle at once, complete argument support.

Literati now has an 'all' action that will both tangle and weave the
files you give it.
You can also pass in a path to an individual file, an entire directory
to be operated on, and a mix of the above (multiple files and a
directory) and literati will process them all for you dutifully.
commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.message:
Preserve new lines in code segments.

To increase readability in the output files, literati will preserve
whitespace lines in code, so that even the tangled output files will be
formatted similarly to the code in the literati source files.
commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.repo_description: Literate programming for Ruby

commit_list.message:
Improved tangle/weave file output behavior.

A few changes in this commit:
- By default, a command will apply to all literati files from the current
  working directory, recursively into all sub directories.
- Output files are now put in a directory called 'output' in the working
  directory, with tangled files going into the 'src' subdirectory, and
  weaved files going int othe 'doc' subdirectory
- You can specify a directory structure in the file block name,
  and literati will respect this.

From here, with just a './literati.rb tangle', you should be able to
build literati entirely, and just move the contents of the output file.

commit_list.message:
Finished Pang, the Pong clone

I have cut a few features, and made some final polishing changes, and am
calling this game done.

I changed the splash screen and the menu to suit the new look. I removed
the splash music because it didn't match with the feel of the game.

I scrapped a new splash graphic and new splash music, on account of not
having the skill to do either. I also scrapped the AI paddle idle polish
because I'm quickly running out of steam on this little game.

It's done!
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished game part of Pang - just need polish

I have created game ending flows with winning and losing screens, and
the game can now determine when the winning score (12 right now) has
been reached, and whether the player or the AI won.

I have also moved the score keeping off of the ball (which never made
sense) and put it in the game.

I have also fixed a few bugs with bouncing and waiting on the menu too
long causing the player to lose the first point.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Fixed AI, sounds and bouncing

Added refinements to the AI logic that will mean the AI can be beaten.
This required slowing the paddles down so that they're not fast enough
to beat the ball to the other side of the stage, but it didn't
negatively affect balance.

I also fixed and simplified the bouncing logic so that the ball bounces
how you'd expect it to.

I also added sound for when the ball goes off the stage.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Added more polish to Pang

I started a Trello board so I can track my progress on polishing Pang.
Here is the list of features I completed in this commit:
* Draw top and bottom bars on the GUI
* Fix scoring so that player 1 can score when the AI paddle misses the
  ball
* Change how scores are drawn (font and positioning)
* Fix serve direction after winning a point (serves to loser)

The Trello board is really helping keep track of what needs to be
completed.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Added scoring to the game

Added simple scoring. Right now the game does not end when a person gets
to a certain score, but that will be next!
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Added a GUI for the game

Right now it's just implemented as a class that writes out test text,
but eventually it will read the state from the ... ball? Or somewhere,
and then will display the score on the screen.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Fixed AI so that it can anticipate wall bounces

The AI can now anticipate where the ball is going to land after it
bounces from the wall, and will move there to catch it after the bounce.

AI is very sneaky.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Fixed jittery AI paddle

Gave the AI paddle the ability to predict where the ball will be,
without taking into account bouncing from walls. Also the AI paddle
tracks the ball's position only when the ball is coming towards it. When
the ball is heading towards the user paddle, the AI paddle tracks it
within a threshold.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Refactored the game a little and fixed bugs with ball interaction

I have refactored common paddle functionality into an abstract base
class, Paddle. I have implemented paddle/ball interaction within a loop,
so that both the AI paddle and the player paddle have the same
restrictions and abilities.

I have fixed a few bugs in the interaction of the ball and the paddles,
and added some new behavior. Now when you strike the ball with the side
of your paddle, it will deflect off screen and you will lose, instead of
it moving to the top of the paddle and reflecting back.

Now there are 2 more known issues to fix before I move into a scoring
system - one with the AI jitter, and one with the ball speed coming off
of a paddle hit. Sometimes you can hit the ball multiple times and it
will vastly increase it's speed.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished part 9 of Game From Scratch tutorial

Implemented an AI paddle that will follow the ball around on the x axis,
and removed the code that allows the ball to bounce off the top of the
screen.

All we need to do is to implement a scoring system and a win/lose
sequence, and we will have a very buggy, very ugly game.

Given that this is where the tutorials end on the Game from Scratch
website, I will continue alone. Next I will implement scoring and a UI
for score keeping, and I will implement winning/losing sequences.

After that, I will fix the bugs with ball collisions and AI, and tweak
the controls so that it doesn't feel so sluggish.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished part 8 and half of part 9 of Game from Scratch tutorial

Implemented sounds using the service locator design pattern. I bundled
part 8 and half of part 9 together because part 8 introduced you to the
service locator design pattern, and implemented it poorly. Part 9 went
back and fixed that implementation.

Rather than just implementing a crappy version, I went right ahead and
implemented the more clean version.

I also changed some of the sounds the tutorial uses, generated them with
cfxr.

This has uncovered a really annoying bug in the collision detection
code, which I will fix once I go back and polish the project.

The first 90% is nearly done, then I can start on the last 90%.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished part 7 of the Games from Scratch tutorial

Implemented ball movement and paddle intersection. We almost have a
playable game.

I'm noticing parts that I can refactor away and improve upon the design
of the game, so I might do that after I have finished the tutorial.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished part 6 of the Games from Scratch tutorial

In this part, we implemented the ball we're going to play with, and
movement for the paddle. I also marked locations where I believe
refactoring would be good, and I also deviated a little from the
tutorial when it game to the paddle's behavior and bouncing from the
walls.

The original tutorial had a bug where if the paddle's velocity was too
big, if you hit the edge of the game it would slowly move out of the
window. I fixed that issue, and you can see what my fix was. I didn't
document the fix in the literati source code, as I believe the actual
code is clear enough.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished chapter 5 of the Games from Scratch - C++ Edition

We implemented a game object manager that manages memory for game
objects, and allows us to abstract away the rendering so we don't have
to manually render objects.

This should eliminate memory leaks (kind of, I think there are still
leaks in the menu and splash screen), and although a little overkill for
a pong clone, it is a useful technique for larger games.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished part 4 of the Games from Scratch tutorial

Added a player paddle, and enabled users to exit from the game to the
main menu.

Everything is a little rough right now, and in part 5 we will clean some
of this stuff up.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Finished the 3rd part of the Games from Scratch tutorial

Implemented a splash screen and a menu system. The game will now boot
into a splash screen, where you will have to click to continue. Then you
are presented with a main menu, where you can choose to play the game or
exit.
commit_list.repo_description: Following the Games from Scratch C++ tutorial

commit_list.message:
Initial commit

The initial commit of the Games From Scratch C++ edition tutorial. In
this tutorial we will be making a Pong clone, called Pang, using C++ and
SFML. This is a great first game project for an aspiring gamedev like
myself.

commit_list.message:
Moved from sylvester to mjs for math, moved and fixed rotation and
translation, made these chainable.

The side effects of moving from sylvester to mjs also mean that vertices
and matrices are represented with plain arrays, which makes performing
matrix operations on more complex objects like faces much easier.

commit_list.repo_description: 3D modeling in the browser

commit_list.message:
To help cross-browser (Chrome and Firefox thus far) development and
debugging, I've added a new Debugger (console).
This debugger allows me to log either to a built in console (Chrome
and Safari) or an extension (Firebug), or directly to the page.
Multiple instances of this debugger can be created, but there is a
global $C.

In the future, consider renaming it to debug/Console.js instead.
commit_list.repo_description: 3D modeling in the browser

commit_list.message:
Previously to this commit, instances of Object3D assigned their own
IDs based on the current timestamp and a randomized number.
This commit changes the way instances of Object3D obtain their ID.
Object3D exposes functionality to set the ID of an instance if the ID
is not set already. If the ID is set, it is not changed.
Scene now sets the ID on children as they are added, based on an
internal object counter.

This makes ID assignment more deterministic and predictable, which
will avoid potential bugs in the future with clashing IDs.
